Text: Developing ethical brochures and other materials used to attract job applicants.
Attracting and selecting employees who demonstrate responsible values or behavior.
Hiring employees who exhibit relatively high levels of moral development.
Induction programs that emphasize responsible and sustainable values (e.g., dignity, solidarity, and reciprocity).
Organization-wide training to develop responsible and sustainable behavior.
Presence of ethical leadership programs and extensive training on ethical and sustainability issues.
Creating cognitive conflict to stimulate independent decisions in ethically ambiguous situations.
Developing employee skills in engaging and communicating with multiple stakeholders (e.g., customers, suppliers, government, community, and the public, media).
Developing performance goals that focus on means as well as ends, using not only outcome-based but also behavior-based performance evaluations.
Linking bonuses and variable pay to ethical, responsible, and sustainable behaviors based on social performance objectives.
Promoting awards for good citizenship and moral behavior.
Sanctions for managers and employees who breach the organization's sustainability standards.
Job design encourages employees to take ethics related decisions.
Presence of employee volunteer programs and/or charitable giving opportunities.
Encouraging members to provide solutions when the organization faces ethical problems.
Involving employee representatives and unions in the design, application, and review of the ethical infrastructure of the company.
The career mechanism is fair, visible to all, and linked to organizational ethical and sustainability standards.
Employee surveys in place to monitor the ethical climate of the organization.
Encouraging the reporting of unethical behavior and supporting whistleblowing on ethical issues.
